title: Psalms Chapter 59 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 59 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 59 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 59.

questions.question: Who sent men to watch the house to kill David, as mentioned in Psalms 59?
questions.correctAnswer: Saul
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:1 states that Saul sent men to watch the house to kill David.

questions.question: According to Psalms 59:2, from whom does David ask God to deliver him?
questions.correctAnswer: Workers of iniquity
questions.explanation: David prays for deliverance from workers of iniquity and bloody men as stated in Psalms 59:2.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 59:3 says that David's enemies gathered against him because of his transgressions.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:3 says the mighty gathered against David not for his transgression or sin.

questions.question: What does David ask God to do in Psalms 59:4?
options: Awake to help him and behold
questions.correctAnswer: Awake to help him and behold
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:4 requests God to awake to help David and look upon his situation.

questions.question: In Psalms 59:5, God is called the God of which people?
questions.correctAnswer: Israel
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:5 refers to the LORD God of hosts, the God of Israel.

questions.question: According to Psalms 59:6, what noise do David’s enemies make at evening?
questions.correctAnswer: Like a dog
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:6 describes the enemies making noise like a dog at evening.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 59:7: 'Behold, they belch out with their mouth: swords are in their ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: lips
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:7 states that swords are in their lips.

questions.question: What will the LORD do to the enemies according to Psalms 59:8?
options: Laugh at them and hold all heathen in derision
questions.correctAnswer: Laugh at them and hold all heathen in derision
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:8 says the LORD shall laugh at them and have all heathen in derision.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 59:9 says David will wait upon God because of His mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:9 says David will wait upon God because of His strength, not mercy.

questions.question: What does David say God will let him see upon his enemies, according to Psalms 59:10?
questions.correctAnswer: His desire
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:10 states God shall let David see his desire upon his enemies.

questions.question: According to Psalms 59:11, why does David ask God not to slay his enemies completely?
questions.correctAnswer: Lest my people forget
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:11 says not to slay them so the people won't forget.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 59:12 attributes the enemies' capture to the sin of their mouth and lying lips.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:12 explains that their pride and lying words cause their capture.

questions.question: What does David say God rules in Psalms 59:13?
options: Jacob unto the ends of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob unto the ends of the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:13 states God rules in Jacob unto the ends of the earth.

questions.question: According to Psalms 59:14, what do the enemies do at evening?
options: Return and make noise like a dog
questions.correctAnswer: Return and make noise like a dog
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:14 repeats that enemies return at evening and make noise like dogs.

questions.question: According to Psalms 59:16, when does David sing aloud of God's mercy?
questions.correctAnswer: In the morning
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:16 says David sings aloud of God's mercy in the morning.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 59 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 59 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A friend is facing opposition at work from dishonest colleagues. Based on Psalms 59, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God in such trials?
options: God is our defense and refuge in times of trouble.
We should seek revenge to protect ourselves.
Ignoring the situation is the best approach.
We must handle it all by our own strength.
questions.correctAnswer: God is our defense and refuge in times of trouble.
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:9, 16, and 17 emphasize trusting God as a strong defense and refuge during adversity, encouraging reliance on His protection.

questions.question: How does Psalms 59 teach us about praying for justice instead of personal vengeance when wronged?
options: Pray that God scatters the enemies by His power but not to kill them.
Immediately punish those who harm us without mercy.
Ignore wrongdoing and pretend it never happened.
Seek personal revenge to satisfy our anger.
questions.correctAnswer: Pray that God scatters the enemies by His power but not to kill them.
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:11 instructs to ask God to scatter enemies by His power without killing them, so people remember and learn, showing a prayer for justice rather than personal vengeance.

questions.question: In dealing with persistent temptation or trials, what attitude does Psalms 59 encourage us to maintain?
options: Wait confidently on God's strength and mercy.
Give up because the trials are too hard.
Rely solely on human wisdom to escape trouble.
Hide from the problem and avoid confrontation.
questions.correctAnswer: Wait confidently on God's strength and mercy.
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:9 and 10 highlight waiting upon God's strength and mercy as a source of hope and deliverance amid trials.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with bitterness toward those who speak falsely against them. What biblical teaching from Psalms 59 can you share about handling such situations?
options: Trust God to consume the wicked in His wrath but continue to sing of His mercy.
Harbor bitterness and seek to retaliate immediately.
Ignore God and try to forget the offense.
Confront them with harsh words to defend your honor.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to consume the wicked in His wrath but continue to sing of His mercy.
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:13 and 16 teach to rely on God's justice while maintaining a heart of praise and trust in His mercy.

questions.question: How does Psalms 59 teach us about humility and contentment during times of opposition?
options: Sing of God's power and mercy even in the morning of trouble.
Boast about overcoming enemies by personal strength.
Complain loudly about adversaries without trust in God.
Isolate oneself from others to avoid conflict.
questions.correctAnswer: Sing of God's power and mercy even in the morning of trouble.
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:16 encourages praising God’s power and mercy despite difficulties, reflecting humility and contentment in God’s care.

questions.question: What does Psalms 59 teach about integrity and honesty in the face of slander?
options: God rules and judges the words of the wicked who speak lies.
Respond to slander with more lies to defend yourself.
Ignore the truth and accept false accusations.
Seek to silence others by intimidation.
questions.correctAnswer: God rules and judges the words of the wicked who speak lies.
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:12-13 reveals that God will judge the sin and lies spoken by enemies, teaching believers to trust God’s righteousness rather than retaliating dishonestly.

questions.question: How does Psalms 59 encourage us to pray for those who oppose us?
options: Ask God not to be merciful to wicked transgressors.
Pray for their immediate destruction without mercy.
Ignore them completely and refuse to pray.
Join in their wrongdoing to gain favor.
questions.correctAnswer: Ask God not to be merciful to wicked transgressors.
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:5 specifically requests God to visit the heathen and not show mercy to wicked transgressors, reflecting a call for divine justice.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 59, God laughs at the plans of the enemies who rise against His people.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:8 states that the LORD shall laugh at the enemies and hold all the heathen in derision, showing God’s sovereign power over them.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 59 advises believers to kill their enemies to ensure they do not forget their wrongdoing.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:11 explicitly says not to slay enemies so that the people do not forget, but to scatter them by God's power, indicating restraint and reliance on God’s justice.

questions.question: Complete the verse: "Let them wander up and down for ___, and grudge if they be not satisfied."
questions.correctAnswer: meat
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:15 uses this imagery showing the restless pursuit of evil men, emphasizing the futility of their efforts and God’s ultimate control.

questions.question: How does Psalms 59 illustrate the importance of faithfulness in prayer during persecution?
options: David consistently calls on God to deliver and defend him despite ongoing threats.
David stops praying after initial failures.
David advises using human tactics to avoid enemies.
David ignores the trouble and focuses on other matters.
questions.correctAnswer: David consistently calls on God to deliver and defend him despite ongoing threats.
questions.explanation: Throughout Psalms 59 (e.g., verses 1-4, 9, 16-17), David persistently prays to God for deliverance showing faithfulness in prayer during trials.

questions.question: What spiritual discipline is modeled in Psalms 59 by David when he acknowledges God as his strength?
options: Worship through singing and declaring God's power and mercy.
Isolating oneself from others during hardship.
questions.correctAnswer: Worship through singing and declaring God's power and mercy.
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:16-17 shows David’s practice of worship and praise as a spiritual discipline, demonstrating trust and gratitude to God.

questions.question: How does Psalms 59 teach about perseverance through trials for believers facing false accusations?
options: Continue to trust God’s justice and mercy while waiting patiently.
Abandon faith because trials are unfair.
Withdraw from community and isolate oneself.
questions.correctAnswer: Continue to trust God’s justice and mercy while waiting patiently.
questions.explanation: Verses like Psalms 59:9-10 encourage waiting on God's strength and mercy, highlighting perseverance in faith despite adversaries.

questions.question: A believer wonders how to maintain integrity when surrounded by deceit. What lesson does Psalms 59 provide?
options: Trust God to judge the deceitful and uphold righteousness.
Ignore the deceit and pretend all is well.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to judge the deceitful and uphold righteousness.
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:12-13 shows God’s role as judge over lies and curses, encouraging believers to maintain integrity and trust God's justice.

questions.question: What does Psalms 59 teach about the believer’s attitude toward enemies who are like dogs making noise around the city?
options: God will laugh at their futile attempts and hold them in derision.
We should retaliate loudly to match their noise.
We must be afraid and hide from them.
We should join their noisy behavior.
questions.correctAnswer: God will laugh at their futile attempts and hold them in derision.
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:6-8 describes enemies as noisy dogs, but God laughs at them, highlighting the futility of their efforts and God's sovereignty.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 59 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 59.

questions.question: In Psalms 59:1, what is the primary request David makes to God?
questions.correctAnswer: Deliver me from mine enemies
questions.explanation: David asks God to deliver him from his enemies who seek to kill him, as stated in Psalms 59:1.

questions.question: What term used in Psalms 59:1 describes the musical direction for this Psalm, and what is its significance in Hebrew worship?
options: Michtam, denoting a golden or precious poem
Shiggaion, a passionate or emotional song
questions.correctAnswer: Altaschith, meaning 'do not destroy'
questions.explanation: The heading in Psalms 59:1 includes 'Altaschith', a term meaning 'do not destroy', reflecting a plea for preservation, significant in Hebrew worship as an instruction for the music.

questions.question: According to Psalms 59:3, why do David's enemies gather against him?
options: Not for his transgression nor for his sin
Because of his pride and arrogance
Due to his failure in leadership
Because of his wealth and possessions
questions.correctAnswer: Not for his transgression nor for his sin
questions.explanation: David emphasizes in Psalms 59:3 that his enemies gather against him unjustly, not because of any sin or transgression.

questions.question: In Psalms 59:5, David calls God by a specific title emphasizing divine military power. Which title is it?
questions.correctAnswer: God of hosts
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:5 refers to God as 'O LORD God of hosts,' highlighting His role as commander of heavenly armies, a common Old Testament theme emphasizing divine power.

questions.question: What simile is used in Psalms 59:6 to describe the enemies' behavior in the city?
options: They make a noise like a dog
questions.correctAnswer: They make a noise like a dog
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:6 uses the simile 'make a noise like a dog' to depict the enemies’ futile and irritating activity around the city.

questions.question: What literary device is employed in Psalms 59:7 with the phrase 'swords are in their lips'?
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor indicating harmful speech
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:7 uses a metaphor where 'swords are in their lips' to depict the enemies’ words as weapons, emphasizing the danger of their speech.

questions.question: How does Psalms 59:8 portray God's attitude toward the enemies?
options: God laughs at them and holds all heathen in derision
questions.correctAnswer: God laughs at them and holds all heathen in derision
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:8 states that God will laugh at the enemies and have all the heathen in derision, indicating divine contempt and sovereign superiority.

questions.question: What phrase in Psalms 59:9 reveals David’s reason for waiting on the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Because of his strength
questions.explanation: David declares in Psalms 59:9 that he waits on God because of God's strength, showing reliance on divine power for defense.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the Hebrew word 'Michtam' found in the title of Psalms 59, and how does it relate to the Psalm’s content?
options: A golden poem, indicating preciousness and depth
questions.correctAnswer: A golden poem, indicating preciousness and depth
questions.explanation: The term 'Michtam' in Psalms 59:1 is often translated as 'golden poem,' highlighting the Psalm’s refined and precious nature, reflecting deep personal lament and trust.

questions.question: In Psalms 59:11, why does David ask God not to slay his enemies outright?
options: Because he wants them to repent
questions.correctAnswer: Lest my people forget
questions.explanation: David requests in Psalms 59:11 that God scatter his enemies by power but not slay them, so that his people remember and learn from the event.

questions.question: How do the enemies’ words contribute to their downfall according to Psalms 59:12?
options: Their pride, cursing, and lying ensnare them
questions.correctAnswer: Their pride, cursing, and lying ensnare them
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:12 describes that the enemies’ own sinful words—pride, cursing, and lying—lead to their capture and downfall.

questions.question: Which Old Testament theme is reflected in Psalms 59:13’s declaration that God rules in Jacob unto the ends of the earth?
options: God’s sovereign kingship over Israel and all nations
The exile and return of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereign kingship over Israel and all nations
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:13 affirms the theme of God’s universal rule, a common motif in the Old Testament emphasizing divine sovereignty over Israel and the nations.

questions.question: What repeated imagery in Psalms 59:6 and Psalms 59:14 links the enemies’ behavior, and what might it symbolize culturally?
options: Making noise like a dog, symbolizing contempt and nuisance
questions.correctAnswer: Making noise like a dog, symbolizing contempt and nuisance
questions.explanation: Both verses use the imagery of dogs making noise, a metaphor culturally associated with uncleanness and relentless annoyance in the ancient Near East.

questions.question: In Psalms 59:16, David commits to singing about two aspects of God. What are they?
questions.correctAnswer: Power and mercy
questions.explanation: David declares in Psalms 59:16 that he will sing of God's power and mercy, highlighting divine attributes that provide defense and refuge.

questions.question: True or False: In Psalms 59:10, David expresses confidence that God will prevent him and allow him to see his desire upon his enemies.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:10 clearly states that God’s mercy will prevent David and allow him to see his desire upon his enemies, reflecting trust in divine protection.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 59 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 59 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Psalms 59, David asks God to defend him specifically against whom?
options: Workers of iniquity and bloody men
questions.correctAnswer: Workers of iniquity and bloody men
questions.explanation: David explicitly requests deliverance from 'workers of iniquity' and 'bloody men' as seen in Psalms 59:2. This emphasizes God's role as protector against evil human agents, consistent with passages like Psalm 7:9, Psalm 140:1, Romans 12:19, and 2 Thessalonians 3:3.

questions.question: What reason does David give for the enemies' aggression in Psalms 59?
options: Not for transgression nor for sin
questions.correctAnswer: Not for transgression nor for sin
questions.explanation: David states in Psalms 59:3 that the mighty are gathered against him 'not for my transgression, nor for my sin,' showing an innocent suffering motif similar to Job 1:1, Isaiah 53:9, 1 Peter 2:22, and Acts 3:14.

questions.question: How does David describe the enemies' behavior in the city at evening?
options: They make a noise like a dog and go around the city
They worship idols and burn incense
questions.correctAnswer: They make a noise like a dog and go around the city
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:6 describes the enemies as making noise like dogs and prowling the city, symbolizing restless and aggressive hostility, paralleling Psalm 22:16, Proverbs 26:11, Matthew 7:6, and Philippians 3:2.

questions.question: Which divine attribute is emphasized in Psalms 59:8 when God 'laughs' at the enemies?
options: God's sovereignty and derision of the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: God's sovereignty and derision of the wicked
questions.explanation: The laughter at the enemies in Psalms 59:8 highlights God's sovereign control and contempt for evil, consistent with Job 41:11, Psalm 2:4, Proverbs 1:26, and Revelation 19:11 where God's rule over evil is affirmed.

questions.question: According to Psalms 59:11, why does David request that God not slay his enemies outright?
options: Lest his people forget and instead scatter them by power
Because he wants to forgive them
So they can repent and be saved
questions.correctAnswer: Lest his people forget and instead scatter them by power
questions.explanation: David asks for enemies to be scattered rather than killed to keep his people mindful of God's protection (Psalms 59:11). This teaching aligns with Deuteronomy 32:35, Romans 12:19, Hebrews 10:30, and Psalm 37:12-15 regarding divine justice and remembrance.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'The God of my ______ shall prevent me; God shall let me see my desire upon mine enemies.'
questions.correctAnswer: mercy
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:10 states 'The God of my mercy shall prevent me,' emphasizing God's protective mercy, which is a key attribute also seen in Exodus 34:6, Lamentations 3:22, Ephesians 2:4, and Titus 3:5.

questions.question: In Psalms 59, what metaphor is used to describe the enemies' speech in verse 7?
questions.correctAnswer: Swords are in their lips
questions.explanation: Verse 7 uses the metaphor 'swords are in their lips' to depict destructive and violent speech, echoing imagery in Psalm 57:4, Proverbs 12:18, Isaiah 59:7, and Ephesians 4:29 about the power of words.

questions.question: How does David express his confidence in God's protection in Psalms 59:9?
options: Because of His strength will I wait upon thee
I will fight my enemies with my own hands
I will hide and avoid all confrontation
I will seek help from earthly kings
questions.correctAnswer: Because of His strength will I wait upon thee
questions.explanation: David's confidence comes from relying on God's strength (Psalms 59:9), consistent with Psalm 18:2, Isaiah 40:31, 2 Corinthians 12:9, and Philippians 4:13 about trusting divine strength.

questions.question: What does David declare he will do in the morning as an act of worship according to Psalms 59:16?
questions.correctAnswer: Sing aloud of God's mercy
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:16 reveals David's commitment to sing aloud of God's mercy each morning, highlighting joyful worship, similar to Psalm 30:5, Psalm 92:2, Isaiah 12:2, and Hebrews 13:15.

questions.question: Which title for God is prominently used throughout Psalms 59 to emphasize His power and protection?
questions.correctAnswer: God of hosts
questions.explanation: David calls God 'God of hosts' in Psalms 59:5, underscoring His command over heavenly armies, a title also found in 1 Samuel 17:45, Isaiah 6:3, Jeremiah 10:16, and Zechariah 14:5 denoting divine omnipotence.

questions.question: What does Psalms 59:13 say is the ultimate purpose of God consuming the wicked?
options: That they may know God ruleth in Jacob unto the ends of the earth
To erase all memory of their existence
To prepare them for eternal punishment
To make room for the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: That they may know God ruleth in Jacob unto the ends of the earth
questions.explanation: Verses 13 states God consumes the wicked so they recognize His sovereign rule over Israel and the earth, paralleling Psalm 103:19, Daniel 4:17, Romans 9:17, and Revelation 11:15 on God's universal reign.

questions.question: What recurring imagery in Psalms 59 depicts the enemies as scavengers or wild animals?
options: Making noise like a dog and wandering for meat
Flying like eagles over the city
Swimming like fish in the river
Roaring like lions in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: Making noise like a dog and wandering for meat
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:6 and 15 compare enemies to dogs making noise and wandering for food, symbolizing their restless, predatory nature, as also seen in Psalm 22:16, Matthew 7:6, Philippians 3:2, and 2 Peter 2:22.

questions.question: Who is called 'my strength' and 'my defence' in Psalms 59:17?
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: David addresses God as 'my strength' and 'my defence' in Psalms 59:17, affirming God's protective and empowering role, consistent with Psalm 28:7, Psalm 46:1, Isaiah 12:2, and Ephesians 6:10.

questions.question: In Psalms 59, what does David ask God to do with the pride of the enemies as a consequence of their sin and lying?
options: Let them be taken in their pride
questions.correctAnswer: Let them be taken in their pride
questions.explanation: Psalms 59:12 requests that enemies be caught through their own pride due to their sinful speech, aligning with Proverbs 16:18, Isaiah 2:12, 1 Timothy 3:6, and James 4:6 on the downfall of pride.

questions.question: What does David anticipate about God's justice in Psalms 59:13?
options: God will consume the wicked in wrath so they know He rules
God will forgive all without consequence
questions.correctAnswer: God will consume the wicked in wrath so they know He rules
questions.explanation: David proclaims that God will consume the wicked in wrath (Psalms 59:13) to demonstrate His sovereignty, a theme supported by Romans 1:18, Nahum 1:2, Hebrews 10:31, and Revelation 19:15.
